questiontext.text:
Even and odd functions (continued)

A Fourier series contains a sum of terms while the integral formulae for the Fourier coefficients \(a_n\) and \(b_n\) contain products of the type \(f(t) \cos nt\) and \(f(t) \sin nt\). We need therefore results for sums and products of functions.

Suppose, for example, \(g(t)\) is an odd function and \(h(t)\) is an even function.

\[ \begin{align} \text{Let } \hspace{1cm} F_1(t) &= g(t)h(t) \hspace{1cm} \text{(product of odd and even functions)} \\ \text{so } \hspace{0.9cm} F_1(-t) &= g(-t)h(-t) \hspace{1cm} \text{(replacing } t \text{ with } -t \text{)} \\ &= (-g(t))h(t) \hspace{1cm} \text{(since } g \text{ is odd and } h \text{ is even)} \\ &= -g(t)h(t) \\ &= F_1(t) \end{align} \] So \(F_1(t) is odd.

Now suppose \[ \begin{align} F_2(t) &= g(t) + h(t) \hspace{1cm} \text{(sum of odd and even functions)} \\ \therefore \hspace{1cm} F_2(-t) &= g(-t) + h(t) \\ &= -g(t) + h(t) \end{align} \] We see that \[ F_2(-t) \neq F_2(t) \] and \[F_2(-t) \neq -F_2(t) \] So \(F_2(t)\) is neither odd nor even.
